2.81.text:
>>Tim O'Reilly: one question I'd like to start
with, Ray, is the question of choices. You

13.65.text:
know, your graphs have this remarkable sense
of inevitability about them.

19.71.text:
And, yet, we know in our everyday life and
we know in the life of nations that there

27.05.text:
are choices to be made and that, if we make
the wrong choice -- at least in the short-term

33.07.text:
-- things can go very wrong. At least there's
evidence from history that they can go very

39.09.text:
wrong for a long time. One of the things -- I
think, being trained as a classist original,

45.46.text:
I think about things like the fact that the
Hagia Sophia was the largest building in the

50.10.text:
world for a thousand years. It's not -- when
progress failed in the west, the western Roman

57.07.text:
empire, moved to the eastern Roman empire,
moved to the Arabic world and back to Europe,

63.80.text:
you know, we're increasingly one world. And
we screw up, we screw up for everybody.

69.12.text:
>>Ray Kurzweil: In terms of inevitability,
sometimes people say why don't we just sit

72.91.text:
back and let it happen? Why are we working
so hard? If we did that, it wouldn't happen.

78.30.text:
In a way, we're counting on people's passion
to follow their inspiration and be creative

86.45.text:
and the increasing enabling of the democratization
of the tools of innovation, which I talked

92.07.text:
about.
However, there's another reason to get involved.

95.23.text:
They say war is too important to leave to
the generals. Technology is too important

99.28.text:
to leave to the technologists. I talked somewhat
about the promise, but there's also peril.

104.91.text:
The same technology we're using to reprogram
biology away from disease could be also be

109.72.text:
applied by a bioterrorist to reprogram a biological
virus to be a deadly weapon. We're not defenseless

117.00.text:
against that. We can create a defensive system.
I've been working, actually, with the Army

121.93.text:
on doing that, a rapid response system for
biological viruses like we do have for software

127.18.text:
viruses. But there is promise and peril. That's
been true of technology since fire, which

133.54.text:
kept us warm but also burned down our villages.
And that's the reason to get involved. And

138.44.text:
there are also subtle issues that are important
beyond the existential risks. Privacy, protection

145.60.text:
of intellectual property so that we can actually
create information of value and so on.

151.80.text:
>>Tim O'Reilly: So let me shift over to your
focus on health and wellness as IT. I think

159.34.text:
there's an enormous opportunity there. Some
of it is in areas like genomics. But there

164.43.text:
are also enormous opportunities just in creating
learning loops. You know, one of the things

170.41.text:
I like to think about with Google and advertising,
of course, this being a conference that has

176.79.text:
its roots in that world, one of the amazing
things we learned was how to solve what you

183.41.text:
could describe as the Wanamaker problem. You
know, half of my advertising doesn't work.

187.43.text:
I just don't know which half. Google made
a big dent in solving that problem for a certain

191.49.text:
class of advertising. As we move into healthcare
as IT, we're actually trying to do that same

198.55.text:
thing. We're, actually, trying to use collective
intelligence, massive amounts of data to actually

203.57.text:
figure out what's working and what isn't.
>>Ray Kurzweil: There's many aspects of that.

207.32.text:
There's actual collective decision making
using the tools that are becoming available.

214.01.text:
Patients are perfectly good scientific and
medical researchers. And groups of patients

218.81.text:
are -- have a motivation to solve a disease.
And that is happening. And patient goes into

225.16.text:
a doctor's office with a chronic disease,
she is armed with the latest knowledge from,

230.05.text:
you know, whole community of people who have
that and who have a passion for addressing

234.83.text:
that condition. And she may very well know
more about it than her physician.

239.18.text:
>>Tim O'Reilly: That kind of brings me back
to an issue of choices. You know, one of the

243.77.text:
big areas that I know when I talk to people
in medical research, some of the privacy fears

250.58.text:
actually are holding us back. You know, patients
will quite willingly share their medical history

256.15.text:
with other patients, if you look at a community
like patients like me, people are sharing

261.52.text:
everything they know, because, my gosh, they're
trying to save their life.

266.00.text:
Yet, our system penalizes people, makes it
difficult to share.

270.90.text:
Do we need to change our culture of data sharing
in areas like this?

274.92.text:
>>Ray Kurzweil: Yes, I think so. HIPAA has
slowed down the sharing of data to do outcome

281.21.text:
studies.
There -- that is changing, and there are large

288.09.text:
institutions, like Mayo Clinic and so on,
who are harvesting and harnessing this data

293.58.text:
and stripping off the patient information
and being able to do outcome studies. NIH

300.28.text:
is collecting a million genomes to relate
genetic states to diseases so we can do personalized

305.89.text:
genetic medicine. That wasn't feasible, by
the way, when the genome cost a billion dollars

310.55.text:
each. Now that it's approaching a thousand
dollars each, that becomes feasible.

314.50.text:
So privacy is a very important thing to solve.
I think it is solvable. I think the technologies

320.50.text:
of privacy encryption have kept ahead of the
technologies of breaking privacy, which is

325.83.text:
decryption.
>>Tim O'Reilly: There's kind of another interesting

328.33.text:
element to this health care arena that I find
really instructive, and that is a shift in

336.27.text:
the model from diagnosis at the front end,
followed by treatment, to a situation where

343.51.text:
we're doing constant diagnosis to say, oh,
this treatment working? I was at a recent

347.99.text:
health care event with G.E., and that's a
big part of their focus now, is shifting that

353.01.text:
model. And it really makes a lot of what we've
learned on the consumer Internet so much more

357.92.text:
relevant. Because what we're always doing
is testing, did this work. We're learning

362.05.text:
constantly in our algorithms, gathering new
data. And it's remarkable to me that health

367.24.text:
care is following that same trajectory.
>>Ray Kurzweil: You mentioned Watson. Watson

370.76.text:
is working with nuance, which is -- that's
my first company, actually -- to have it read

379.48.text:
>>Ray Kurzweil: To use it as a diagnostician.
Medical doctors simply cannot read all the

385.48.text:
tens of thousands of articles that come out
each year in their area.

392.59.text:
>>Tim O'Reilly: Yeah, I'm talking, though,
specifically about actual diagnostic devices,

397.85.text:
we look at personalized medicine, you're actually
perhaps looking at the biochemistry, looking

402.37.text:
at the genetics, looking at is this drug actually
working, which patients does it work for,

406.93.text:
which ones does it not work for and you're
tailoring treatment.

410.20.text:
So there's kind of an interesting --
>>Ray Kurzweil: There's a big interest in

412.57.text:
outcome studies, and we've done almost none
of that. You know, in terms of Google's philosophy

418.25.text:
that data is power, which is kind of a variation
of (indiscernible) knowledge is power, having

424.83.text:
that data is tremendously important. Find
people who have taken a particular supplement

429.35.text:
don't get a particular disease, that's really
valuable to know. And that information is

433.91.text:
out there. And it's going to be harvested
now, maybe by Google, but certainly -- or

439.55.text:
by the companies here.
>>Tim O'Reilly: Let me ask you another question:

441.87.text:
You have, you know, famously been, you know,
quoted as saying that, you know, you think

447.81.text:
that it will be possible at some point for
humans to live forever.

451.33.text:
What are the moral implications of that?
>>Ray Kurzweil: Well, it's never forever.

457.43.text:
>>Ray Kurzweil: But come to Google Zeitgeist
and say, I've done it, I've lived forever.

461.44.text:
>>Tim O'Reilly: But certainly --
>>Ray Kurzweil: I think the threshold we're

465.07.text:
going for is to be at more than a year -- add
more of a year to your remaining life expectancy.

470.22.text:
And that's not a guarantee. It's not going
to come suddenly. Bit by bit, as we overcome

475.51.text:
different diseases, reverse aging processes,
all of which is feasible, we will be extending

481.93.text:
human longevity.
Now, if there were the only thing we were

485.32.text:
doing, you could actually make a case that
isn't moral, because we're going to run out

487.85.text:
of resources. But the same technologies that
can extend longevity are going to extend resources.

493.58.text:
I didn't get to discuss, for example, solar
energy, which I worked on with Larry Page

498.01.text:
at the National Academy of Engineering. We
noted that it's growing exponentially. It's

502.91.text:
now a half a percent of the world's energy
needs. But it's doubling every two years,

506.32.text:
and it has been for 25 years. And it's only
eight doublings now from 100%. And people

511.76.text:
tend to dismiss how it's half a percent, it's
a fringe player, not important, but -- and

516.87.text:
they ignore the exponential, just as they
did with the genome and the Internet.

521.10.text:
>>Tim O'Reilly: There are other issues, though,
when you look at a world that's reshaped demographically

526.55.text:
in that way. There's a huge shift in power.
We see right now around the world young people

532.81.text:
without jobs. We -- you know, the question
is, do we really want to shift more people

537.21.text:
-- more power to people who are older?
>>Ray Kurzweil: I don't think the statistics

541.46.text:
show that.
If you look, there's always a lot of political

545.92.text:
consequence on what happened, you know, this
month and this quarter. If you look at it

550.87.text:
over a broad period of time, we have doubled
the percentage of the population working,

556.11.text:
and the jobs pay now ten times as much in
constant dollars compared to a century ago.

561.42.text:
If I were (indiscernible) as a futurist in
1900, I would say a third of you work on farms,

565.63.text:
a third of you work in factories. But in a
hundred years, the year 2000, that's going

569.63.text:
to be 3% and 3%. And everyone would go, "Oh,
my God, we're going to be out of work."

573.97.text:
And I'd say, "Don't worry. You'll get jobs
in genetic sequencing and new search algorithms,"

578.49.text:
and nobody would know what I'm talking about.
Most of the jobs today didn't exist 50 years

583.73.text:
ago, and that will continue to be the case.
And we are investing more in education as

588.12.text:
a result. We had 55,000 college students in
1870. We have ten million today.

591.74.text:
>>Tim O'Reilly: But still, I think the real
implication is, there are enormous disruptions

596.29.text:
ahead, disruptions that aren't just technological,
but social and economic. And we need to actually

602.86.text:
have innovators tackle all of those things.
>>Ray Kurzweil: What's amazing is how quickly

606.67.text:
we get used to change. When things happen,
it's like, wow, it's a search engine where

610.82.text:
you can find out any of the information in
the world in a few seconds. We get used to

615.83.text:
it overnight.
>>Tim O'Reilly: That's right, we do.

617.95.text:
Well, with that, we're going to have to wrap.
We're out of time.

620.64.text:
Thank you very much, Ray.
And --

622.91.text:
[ Applause ]
>>Tim O'Reilly: -- thank you, all for staying
